title: Cardiac Anesthesia Risk Evaluation Score (CARE)
description: The CARE Score predicts mortality and morbidity after cardiac surgery. It is a simple risk classification based on clinical judgment and three clinical variables: comorbid conditions (controlled vs uncontrolled), surgical complexity, and urgency of the procedure.

parameters.name: other_medical_problems
parameters.description: Other medical problems beyond cardiac disease

parameters.name: emergency_surgery
parameters.description: Surgery required as soon as diagnosis is made and operating room is available

parameters.name: last_hope_surgery
parameters.description: Surgery performed as last hope to save or improve life

ranges.interpretation: Stable cardiac disease, no other medical problems, undergoing noncomplex surgery. Lowest risk category with excellent prognosis. Standard perioperative monitoring and care appropriate.
Stable cardiac disease, one or more controlled medical problems, undergoing noncomplex surgery. Low risk with good prognosis. Enhanced monitoring may be considered based on specific comorbidities.

Any uncontrolled medical problem OR undergoing complex surgery. Moderate risk requiring enhanced perioperative monitoring and management. Consider intensive care unit monitoring and specialized cardiac anesthesia techniques.

Any uncontrolled medical problem AND undergoing complex surgery. High risk requiring intensive monitoring, specialized anesthetic management, and likely ICU care. Multidisciplinary approach recommended.

Chronic or advanced cardiac disease undergoing cardiac surgery as last hope to save or improve life. Very high risk with guarded prognosis. Requires maximum perioperative support and family counseling regarding risks.

Emergency surgery (CARE 5 + 1 point for emergency). Extreme risk with very guarded prognosis. Requires immediate operative intervention with maximum perioperative support. Extensive family discussion regarding outcomes essential.

references: Dupuis JY, Wang F, Nathan H, Lam M, Grimes S, Bourke M. The cardiac anesthesia risk evaluation score: a clinically useful predictor of mortality and morbidity after cardiac surgery. Anesthesiology. 2001 Feb;94(2):194-204. doi: 10.1097/00000542-200102000-00006.

Zingone B, Pappalardo A, Dreas L. Logistic versus clinical prediction models: prognostic accuracy of the EuroSCORE and the cardiac anesthesia risk evaluation score. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg. 2004 Nov;26(5):883-7. doi: 10.1016/j.ejcts.2004.07.014.

Ranucci M, Castelvecchio S, Menicanti L, Frigiola A, Pelissero G. A comparison of the EuroSCORE and the Cardiac Anesthesia Risk Evaluation (CARE) score for risk-adjusted mortality analysis in cardiac surgery. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg. 2012 Feb;41(2):307-13. doi: 10.1016/j.ejcts.2011.05.043.
formula: Base CARE category (1-5) determined by cardiac status, medical problems, and surgery complexity + 1 point if emergency surgery
notes: Use in patients undergoing cardiac surgery for risk stratification
Controlled medical problems: stable diabetes, hypertension, etc.
Uncontrolled medical problems: pulmonary edema, renal insufficiency, etc.
Complex surgery: reoperation, combined procedures, multiple valve surgery, etc.
Emergency surgery: required as soon as diagnosis made and OR available
CARE 5: surgery as last hope to save or improve life
Score ranges from 1 (lowest risk) to 6 (emergency + highest risk)
Excellent correlation with postoperative mortality and morbidity
Simple clinical assessment suitable for routine use
